I didn't see any mention of gene testing or otherwize proving that the female was the only parent. If she had 0 access to males and had never been bred by a male I'd beleive it. A few species of reptiles can reproduce thru parthenigenisis, a few species only reproduce this way(but generally still require another female stimulating them to lay fertile eggs, Like mourning geckos). But multiple species of reptiles, fish and amphibians are known to retain sperm from an earlyer breeding to use to produce offspring when conditions are more favorable or to produce multiple batches/clutches/litters/spawns of offspring. Like most livebearers. I have no reason to believe that a bird can't, but this video didn't confirm for me with any data that she didn't just use retained sperm(if posible in this species) or mate without the knowlege of the researchers then for whatever reason attempt to raise without the father bird.

I doubt it is beneficial in removing poor genes from a population.  These genes would remove themselves through natural selection without the help of this process.  Populations of animals will try to grow even if they have poor genes. High population numbers are the best way to get the genetic diversity needed in order to reproduce efficiently.  The benefit for this form of reproduction is that a single bird and fly somewhere remote and start a population. Then other members can fly in to increase the genetic diversity of the group. Here's another observation: Studying these living ecosystems helps us understand past ones. There was a giant Cambrian filter feeder, a form of anomalocaris. Knowing what we know from whales now, we might get an idea of how this ancient creature may have affected our world's atmosphere, when almost all life was aquatic. That would be a fascinating study: Archeo-Ecology.

Until now such a feat had been considered biologically impossible. But the mouse, called Kaguya, was born without the involvement of any sperm or male cell – only female eggs were needed."

The potential benefits to the species of parthenogenesis, in that individuals with two bad alleles will die off while individuals with good alleles will survive more and that parthenotes get two bad alleles more often, is called Kondrashov's hatchet.

It interests me that this happened as males were available.

It would seem to be a beneficial strategy for the species not only would mutations be reduced, but in a single sex environment it would produce mates for other females which would return the sex balance and keep the chicks genetically diverse.
